ai-sn16:1.1.2_0: “Mendicants, Kassapa is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment.

ai-sn16:1.1.3_1: He doesn’t get hold of that robe.
ai-sn16:1.1.3_2: And when they get upset if they use the robe, untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.
ai-sn16:1.2.1_0: Kassapa is content with any kind of almsfood, and praises such contentment.
ai-sn16:1.2.1_1: And they don’t try to take alms-food on account of their roots.

ai-sn16:1.3.1_0: Kassapa is content with any kind of lodging, and praises such contentment.
ai-sn16:1.3.1_1: and they don’t try to take possession of dwellings.
ai-sn16:1.3.1_2: but they don’t get the furniture.
ai-sn16:1.3.1_3: And when they do get things, they use them untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.

ai-sn16:1.4.1_1: they don’t try to get medicines for the sake of medicines and supplies for the sick.

ai-sn16:1.5.1_0: So you should train like this:

ai-sn16:1.5.2_0: We won’t get robes for you,

ai-sn16:2.1.2_0: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa and Venerable Sāriputta were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
ai-sn16:2.1.3_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa,
ai-sn16:2.1.3_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with venerable Mahākassapa.
ai-sn16:2.1.4_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn16:2.1.5_0: “Reverend Kassapa, it’s said that without being keen and prudent you can’t achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn16:2.1.6_0: But if you’re keen and prudent you can achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn16:2.2.1_0: To what extent is this the case?”
ai-sn16:2.2.2_0: And how is someone who is keen and prudent you can achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary?”
ai-sn16:2.2.3_0: “Reverend, take a mendicant who doesn’t foster keenness by thinking: ‘If unarisen unskillful qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unskillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen skillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen skillful qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’
ai-sn16:2.3.1_0: And how are you not prudent?
ai-sn16:2.3.2_0: Take a mendicant who doesn’t foster prudence by thinking: ‘If unarisen unskillful qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unskillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen skillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen skillful qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’
ai-sn16:2.3.4_0: That’s how without being keen and prudent you can’t achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn16:2.4.2_0: Take a mendicant who fosters prudence by thinking: ‘If unarisen unskillful qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unskillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen skillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen skillful qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ...

ai-sn16:2.5.4_0: That’s how if you’re keen and prudent you can achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.”

ai-sn16:5.1.4_0: “You’re old now, Kassapa. Those worn-out hempen rag robes must be a burden for you.

ai-sn16:6.4.3_0: see who can recite more and better and longer?”

ai-sn16:6.4.7_0: see who can recite more and better and longer’?”

ai-sn16:6.5.3_0: see who can recite more and better and longer.
ai-sn16:6.5.4_0: Please accept our confession for our future restraint.”
ai-sn16:6.6.1_0: “Indeed, monks, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way.

ai-sn16:9.2.1_0: Whenever I want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, I enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn16:9.2.2_1: dwells having attained the second absorption.
ai-sn16:9.3.1_0: Whenever I want, with the fading away of rapture, I enter and remain in the third absorption, where I meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware.
ai-sn16:9.3.1_1: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
ai-sn16:9.3.2_1: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
ai-sn16:9.4.1_0: Whenever I want, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-sn16:9.4.2_1: dwells having attained the fourth absorption.
ai-sn16:9.5.1_0: Whenever I want, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, I enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
ai-sn16:9.5.2_1: abides in the sphere of endless space.
ai-sn16:9.6.1_0: Whenever I want, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, I enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
ai-sn16:9.7.1_0: Whenever I want, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, I enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.
ai-sn16:9.8.1_0: Whenever I want, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, I enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-sn16:9.9.1_0: Whenever I want, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, I enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.
ai-sn16:9.10.1_0: Whenever I want, I wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying myself and becoming one again, controlling many kinds of psychic power.
ai-sn16:9.10.1_1: Going forth means strike (different form) or rushing the sky. It was as if they were standing in the air.
ai-sn16:9.10.1_2: They dive into and emerge from the earth, like the water sun.
ai-sn16:9.10.1_3: I’ll come into the water, like the earth.
ai-sn16:9.10.1_4: And I wounded my throat as a bird with wings;
ai-sn16:9.10.1_5: I’ve wield the moon and sun, so mighty and powerful.
ai-sn16:9.10.1_6: controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.
ai-sn16:9.10.2_1: he exercises power as far as the Brahma worlds with his body.
ai-sn16:9.11.1_0: Whenever I want, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, I hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.
ai-sn16:9.12.1_0: Whenever I want, I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with my mind.
ai-sn16:9.12.2_0: I understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,
ai-sn16:9.12.3_0: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’;
ai-sn16:9.12.19_0: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’ ...
ai-sn16:9.13.1_0: Whenever I want, I recollect my many kinds of past lives. That is:
ai-sn16:9.13.1_1: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths.
ai-sn16:9.13.1_2: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food.
ai-sn16:9.13.1_3: I remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

ai-sn16:9.14.1_0: Whenever I want, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-sn16:9.14.1_1: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-sn16:9.14.1_2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-sn16:9.14.1_3: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’
ai-sn16:9.14.1_4: They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they acted out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. ai-sn16:9.14.2_1: and he knows beings arise according to their (good and bad) actions...

ai-sn16:11.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn16:11.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda was wandering in the Southern Hills together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-sn16:11.2.1_0: And at that time thirty of Ānanda’s mendicant pupils resigned the training and returned to a lesser life. Most of them were youths.
ai-sn16:11.2.2_0: When Venerable Ānanda had wandered in the Southern Hills as long as he wished, he set out for Rājagaha.
ai-sn16:11.2.2_1: after approaching and worshipping venerable Mahākassapa, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn16:11.2.2_2: He went up to Venerable Mahākassapa, bowed, and sat down to one side. Mahākassapa said to him:
ai-sn16:11.2.3_0: “Reverend Ānanda, for how many reasons did the Buddha lay down a rule against eating in groups of more than three among families?”
ai-sn16:11.3.1_0: “Sir, the Buddha laid down that rule for three reasons.
ai-sn16:11.3.2_0: For keeping difficult persons in check and for the comfort of good-hearted mendicants. To prevent those of wicked desires from taking sides and dividing the Saṅgha. And out of consideration for families.
ai-sn16:11.3.3_0: These are the three reasons why the Buddha laid down that rule.”
ai-sn16:11.4.1_0: “So what exactly are you doing, wandering together with these junior mendicants? They don’t guard their sense doors, they eat too much, and they’re not committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn16:11.4.2_0: It’s like you’re wandering about wrecking crops and ruining families!
ai-sn16:11.4.3_0: Your following is falling apart, Reverend Ānanda,
ai-sn16:11.4.4_0: It’s fallen off, reverend, and nine days
ai-sn16:11.4.5_0: Yet this boy knows no bounds!”
ai-sn16:11.5.1_0: “Though there are grey hairs on my head,
ai-sn16:11.5.2_0: I still can’t escape being called a boy by Venerable Mahākassapa.”
ai-sn16:11.5.3_0: “It’s because you wander with these junior mendicants. ...

ai-sn16:11.7.1_0: She was upset and blurted out,
ai-sn16:11.7.2_0: “How can Master Mahākassapa, who formerly followed another path, presume to rebuke Master Ānanda the Videhan sage by calling him a boy?”
ai-sn16:11.7.3_0: Mahākassapa heard Thullanandā say these words,
ai-sn16:11.8.2_0: “Indeed, Reverend Ānanda, the nun Thullanandā spoke rashly and without reflection.
ai-sn16:11.8.3_0: Since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, I don’t recall acknowledging any other teacher apart from the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-sn16:11.8.4_0: Formerly when I was still a layman, I thought:
ai-sn16:11.8.5_0: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
ai-sn16:11.8.6_0: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-sn16:11.8.7_0: Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
ai-sn16:11.8.8_0: After some time I made an outer robe of patches and, in the name of the perfected ones in the world, I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn16:11.9.1_0: When I had gone forth, I traveled along the road between Rājagaha and Nālanda, where I saw the Buddha sitting at the Bahuputta Shrine.
ai-sn16:11.9.3_0: ‘If I’m ever to see a Teacher, it would be this Blessed One!
ai-sn16:11.9.4_0: If I’m ever to see a Holy One, it would be this Blessed One!
ai-sn16:11.9.5_0: If I’m ever to see a fully awakened Buddha, it would be this Blessed One!’
ai-sn16:11.9.7_0: Then I bowed with my head at the Buddha’s feet and said:
ai-sn16:11.9.8_0: ‘Sir, the Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple!
ai-sn16:11.9.9_0: The Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple!’
ai-sn16:11.9.10_0: When I said this, the Buddha said,
ai-sn16:11.9.11_0: ‘Kassapa, if anyone was to say to such a wholehearted disciple that they know when they don’t know, or that they see when they don’t see, their head would explode.
ai-sn16:11.9.12_0: But Kassapa, when I say that I know and see I really do know and see.

ai-sn16:12.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa and Venerable Sāriputta were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
ai-sn16:12.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa,
ai-sn16:12.1.2_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with venerable Mahākassapa.
ai-sn16:12.1.3_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn16:12.1.4_0: “Reverend Kassapa, does a Realized One exist after death?”
ai-sn16:12.1.5_0: “Reverend, this has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.1.7_0: “Well then, does a Realized One not exist after death? ...
ai-sn16:12.1.8_0: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.1.9_0: ‘A Realized One doesn’t exist after death’?” ...
ai-sn16:12.1.10_0: “Well then, does a Realized One both exist and not exist after death?”
ai-sn16:12.1.11_0: “Reverend, this has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.1.12_0: ‘A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death’?” ...
ai-sn16:12.1.13_0: “Well then, does a Realized One neither exist nor not exist after death?”
ai-sn16:12.1.14_0: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.1.15_0: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death.’”
ai-sn16:12.1.16_0: “And why has this not been declared by the Buddha?”
ai-sn16:12.1.17_0: “Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn16:12.1.18_0: That’s why it has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.2.1_0: “What has this been declared by the Buddha?”
ai-sn16:12.2.2_0: “‘This is suffering’ has been declared by the Buddha.
ai-sn16:12.2.5_0: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.”
ai-sn16:12.2.6_0: “And why has this been declared by the Buddha?”
ai-sn16:12.2.7_0: “Because it’s beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn16:12.2.8_0: That’s why it has been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:13.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn16:13.1.3_0: Then Venerable Mahākassapa approached the Fortunate One,
ai-sn16:13.1.3_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:
ai-sn16:13.1.4_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why these days there were more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants?
ai-sn16:13.1.5_0: And what is the cause, what is the reason why these days there are more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants?”
ai-sn16:13.1.6_0: “That’s how it is, Kassapa. When sentient beings are in decline and the true teaching is disappearing there are more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants.
ai-sn16:13.1.7_0: The true teaching doesn’t disappear as long the counterfeit of the true teaching hasn’t appeared in the world.
ai-sn16:13.1.8_0: But when the counterfeit of the true teaching appears in the world then the true teaching disappears.
ai-sn16:13.2.1_0: It’s like true gold, which doesn’t disappear as long as counterfeit gold hasn’t appeared in the world.
ai-sn16:13.2.2_0: But when counterfeit gold appears in the world then real gold disappears.
ai-sn16:13.2.3_0: In the same way, as long as the true teaching hasn’t appeared in the world.
ai-sn16:13.2.4_0: But when the counterfeit of the true teaching appears in the world then the true teaching disappears.
ai-sn16:13.3.1_0: It’s not the elements of earth, water, fire, or air that make the true teaching disappear.
ai-sn16:13.3.2_0: Then those foolish men arise here in the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.3.3_0: The true teaching doesn’t disappear like a ship that sinks all at once.
ai-sn16:13.3.4_0: That’s not how the true teaching doesn’t disappear to the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.4.1_0: There are five detrimental things that lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.4.3_0: It’s when the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen lack respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, and immersion.
ai-sn16:13.4.4_0: These five detrimental things lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.5.1_0: There are five things that lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.5.3_0: It’s when the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen maintain respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, and immersion.
ai-sn16:13.5.4_0: These five things lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.”
